Description: Mould-made (amuletic?) figure in glazed composition, in the shape of a squatting figure on a small rectangular base; maybe representation of a monkey or double flute player; scarce remains of turquoise glaze on otherwise pale yellowish very eroded surface; cream fine porous core; only legs and part of base preserved.
Production place: Made in: Egypt, likely Nile Delta
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Antikenmuseum, Heidelberg. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Similar pieces are known from Camirus, Ialysos and Lindos on Rhodes and the Heraion on Samos (Webb 2015 forthcoming). They belong to a varied group of squatting flute-players, either human or in monkey form. They are small figurines, not amulets, because they do not have a suspension loop, or indeed, a back pillar. See examples in Blinkenberg 1931, no 1259a, and b, pl. 55, and Webb 1978, nos. 598-603, p. 100, pl. XV. Webb, V.E.S. 2015 forthcoming, Faience Material from the Samos Heraion Excavations, Samos XIII, Bonn.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.186) (phase 3)
